---
title: Search for Entities
excerpt: The database processes vector search requests using approximate nearest neighbor (ANN) search algorithms.
category: 644ba9105afa34006010ac54
---

When searching for entities on Zilliz Cloud, there are three main search techniques that can be employed. These are:

- **Scalar search**: This is a basic search technique that involves searching for entities based on a single scalar value, such as an ID or a name. Scalar search is easy to use and requires minimal computational resources.

- **Vector search**: This technique involves searching for entities based on their vector representations. In vector databases, entities are represented as vectors of numerical values. Vector search involves comparing the vectors of the entities being searched to find the most similar ones. This technique is more complex than scalar search and requires more computational resources.

- **Hybrid search**: This technique combines both scalar and vector search techniques to provide a more comprehensive search. Hybrid search involves searching for entities based on both scalar values and vector representations. This technique is more accurate than scalar search and less computationally intensive than vector search.

This guide illustrates entity searches with a sample collection created using the [example dataset]().

## Scalar search

The following example searches for titles that are prefixed with the letter **A**.

```shell
curl --location --request POST '<API-Endpoint>/v1/<Cluster-ID>/search' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <API-Key>' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--header 'Accept: */*' \
--header 'Connection: keep-alive' \
--data-raw '{
    "collectionName": "test",
    "filter": "title like \"A%\"",
    "outputFields": [
        "id",
        "title"
    ]
}'
```

The expected result is as follows:

```shell
{
    "code": 200,
    "data": [
        {
            "id": 441056023866793716,
            "title": "Align Your Latents: High-Resolution Video Synthesis with Latent Diffusion Models"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793747,
            "title": "Astral"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793754,
            "title": "Amiga History: The Delfina Plus 16 bit sound card [video]"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793763,
            "title": "An example of LLM prompting for programming"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793767,
            "title": "A WWII spy who hid codes in her knitting"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793774,
            "title": "Apollo dev explains how third-party Reddit apps are affected by API changes"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793776,
            "title": "Ask HN: What would you recommend a 16 year old to pursue career wise?"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793786,
            "title": "A new kind of symmetry shakes up physics"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793793,
            "title": "Apple’s 4.15% Savings Account Marks Golden Age of Cash"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793804,
            "title": "Ampersand (2015)"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793810,
            "title": "A Kubernetes Operator in Rust"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793813,
            "title": "AT&T Wireless traffic shaping apparently making some websites unusable"
        },
        {
            "id": 441056023866793819,
            "title": "Apple’s agreement with Cupertino"
        }
    ]
}
```

## Vector search

The following command searches for titles that are the most similar to the given vector. Results will be the top 5 most similar entities.

```shell
curl --location --request POST '<API-Endpoint>/v1/<Cluster-ID>/search' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <API-Key>' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--header 'Accept: */*' \
--header 'Connection: keep-alive' \
--data-raw '{
    "limit": 5,
    "outputFields": [
        "id",
        "title"
    ],
    "collectionName": "test",
    "title_vector":[
            0.02775966376066208, -0.022234268486499786, 0.0030586274806410074, 0.0017712098779156804, -0.03828269615769386, -0.027015594765543938, -0.04594289883971214, 0.0014836463378742337, The expected result is as follows:
```

```shell
{
    "code": 200,
    "data": [
        {
            "distance": 0,
            "id": 441056023866793736,
            "title": "Why do ships use “port” and “starboard” instead of “left” and “right?”"
        },
        {
            "distance": 1.6067214,
            "id": 441056023866793782,
            "title": "Stop using Telnet to test ports"
        },
        {
            "distance": 1.6939882,
            "id": 441056023866793789,
            "title": "Starlink now available on lakes, seas, and oceans all around the world"
        },
        {
            "distance": 1.7422016,
            "id": 441056023866793823,
            "title": "Misalignment Museum"
        },
        {
            "distance": 1.744637,
            "id": 441056023866793754,
            "title": "Amiga History: The Delfina Plus 16 bit sound card [video]"
        }
    ]
}
```



## Hybrid search

The script below searches for titles that are similar to the given query vector among those that match the condition `title like \"A%\"`. This filter narrows down our search to titles that are prefixed with the letter **A**. To learn more about filters, refer to [Search with Filters]().

```shell
curl --location --request POST '<API-Endpoint>/v1/<Cluster-ID>/search' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <API-Key>' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--header 'Accept: */*' \
--header 'Connection: keep-alive' \
--data-raw '{
    "limit": 5,
    "outputFields": [
        "id",
        "title"
    ],
    "collectionName": "test",
    "level": 1,
    "title_vector":[
            -0.0807134360074997, -0.06857099384069443, 0.07849084585905075, -0.03883836790919304, 0.06851109862327576, -0.09013058245182037, -0.01395935844630003, -0.0008777183247730136, -0.03230762109160423, -0.053183067589998245, -0.06408362090587616, -0.04099440947175026, 0.017911387607455254, -0.038126688450574875, 0.08605968952178955, 0.010451425798237324, -0.0003759561222977936, -0.0728234350681305, -0.0026357576716691256, -0.03490801155567169, 0.019453614950180054, -0.03701082244515419, -0.03181636705994606, -0.030123556032776833, 0.02983737550675869, -0.09249145537614822,         ],
    "filter": "title like \"A%\""
}'
```

The following table describes the fields in the command.

| Field |  Parameter  |
| ----- | --------|
| level   | The precision level of the returned result. Valid values: **1**, **2**, and **3**. A higher value specifies a higher precision level and more accurate result, but this also takes longer to compute. Default value: **1**. |
| collectionName   |  The name of the collection to which this operation applies.  |
| outputFields   | An array of fields to return along with the search results. |
| limit   | The maximum number of entities to return. |
| offset   | The number of entities to skip in the search results. |

## Limits

- The number of returned entities for each query vector, specified by the parameter `limit`, cannot exceed 3,000.
